metadata.case_name: Pannalal Binjraj & Ors. v. Union of India

facts.text: Petitioners Nos. 97 and 97A of 1956 are Pannalal Binjraj (oil mill owners, merchants, commission agents at Sahibganj, branch at Calcutta) and R.B. Jamuna Das Chowdhury (Karta of HUF carrying business as Pannalal Binjraj). Assessed by ITO Special Circle Patna before 28-9-1954.
On 28-9-1954, Central Board of Revenue transferred their cases to ITO Central Circle XI, Calcutta.
On 22-1-1955, cases of petitioner No. 2 transferred to ITO Central Circle VI, Delhi; on 12-7-1955, cases of petitioner No. 1 to same officer.
After transfers, ITO Central Circle VI, Delhi instituted proceedings, issued assessment orders and penalty for non-payment.

Petition No. 44 of 1956: Petitioner A.L. Sud, sole proprietor of Amritlal Sud Construction, resided in Calcutta since 1948, originally from Hoshiarpur. Assessed by ITO Special Survey Circle VII, Calcutta before 29-6-1955.
On 29-6-1955, Central Board transferred his case to ITO Special Circle, Ambala, who continued proceedings and assessed for 1946-47 and 1947-48 under s.23(4).

Petition No. 85 of 1956: Messrs. Bhagwan Das Sud Sons, merchants Hoshiarpur. Case transferred by Commissioner to ITO Special Circle, Ambala. Reopened assessments 1944-45 to 1950-51, completed for 1947-48, 1950-51, 1951-52.
A.L. Sud is member of HUF Bhagwan Das Sud Sons.

Amritsar group (Petitions 86,87,88,111,112,158 of 1956): Sardar Gurdial Singh, Dr. Sarmukh Singh, S. Ram Singh (brothers), S. Narain Singh (father), directors of Hindustan Embroidery Mills Pvt Ltd at Chheharta near Amritsar. Cases transferred on or about 29-6-1953 from ITO A Ward Amritsar to ITO Special Circle Amritsar. Notices u/s 34 for 1947-48 to 1951-52 issued.
Petitioner No. 158: Ram Saran Das Kapur, Karta HUF at Amritsar. Case transferred in 1954 from ITO F Ward Amritsar to ITO Special Circle Amritsar.

Sriram Jhabarmull group (Petitions 211-215 of 1956): Nandram Agarwalla, sole proprietor at Kalimpong, branch Calcutta. Assessments for 1944-45 to 1948-49. Transfers: 15-3-1946 from ITO Jalpaiguri to Central Circle I Calcutta; then to Central Circle IV; 8-6-1946 back to I; 27-7-1946 by Commissioner Central Calcutta u/s 5(7A) to Central Circle IV. Later transfers 1947-48.

Raichur group (225-229 of 1956): Kalloor Siddanna at Raichur, commission agent. Assessed under Hyderabad IT Act till 1949-50. From 1-4-1950 Indian IT Act. On 21-12-1953, Commissioner Hyderabad transferred from Addl ITO Raichur to ITO Special Circle Hyderabad. Assessments made 1955. Then before 19-5-1955 transferred back to main ITO Raichur u/s 5(7A) and 64(5)(b).
Section 5(7A) inserted by IT Amendment Act 1940 (XL of 1940) post Bombay HC in Dayaldas Kushiram.
Explanation to s.5(7A) added by IT Amendment Act 1956 (XXVI of 1956) post Bidi Supply Co.
Petitioners in Sahibganj cases referred to Income-tax Investigation Commission for evasion > Rs.8 lakhs, widespread activities.
After Suraj Mull Mohta, 320 cases reopened u/s 34(1A), allotted to special circles Bombay/Calcutta based on geography.
After Meenakshi Mills, 470 more cases reopened, additional circles created, Sahibganj cases to Central Circle XI Calcutta then to VI Delhi due to workload.
A.L. Sud and HUF Bhagwan Das Sud Sons evaded large amounts, interrelated transactions, widespread activities in multiple places.
Accounts examined at places convenient to assessees, e.g., Sahibganj, Delhi as requested.
Amritsar transfers within same building.
Raichur petitioner ultimately back to local ITO Raichur.
Most petitioners submitted to jurisdiction until after Bidi Supply decision on 20-3-1956.

legal_issues.text: Whether section 5(7A) of the Indian Income-tax Act is ultra vires the Constitution as infringing Articles 14 and 19(1)(g).
Whether specific transfer orders under s.5(7A) are discriminatory or mala fide.
Whether omnibus transfer orders are invalid post Bidi Supply Co., saved by 1956 Explanation.
Whether pre-Constitution transfers (e.g., 1946) challengeable under Arts 14,19.

petitioner_arguments.text: S.5(7A) invests naked arbitrary power to transfer cases without guidelines, discriminatory, picks one assessee over others similarly situated, violates right under s.64(1),(2) to local assessment.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Articles 14, 19(1)(g); s.64(1),(2),(5); Himmatlal Harilal Mehta v. State of MP

petitioner_arguments.text: S.64(5) consequential to invalid s.5(7A), cannot save it.
Omnibus wholesale orders invalid as per Bidi Supply Co. majority and Bose J. minority.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Bidi Supply Co. v. Union of India

petitioner_arguments.text: Transfers cause inconvenience, harassment, upset business.

respondent_arguments.text: S.5(7A) for administrative convenience, to deal with complex cases, widespread activities; no differential procedure, same assessment rights, appeals.
S.64 right not absolute, yields to tax collection exigencies; transfers minimize inconvenience, hearings at convenient places.
Power in high officials CBR/Commissioner, presumption of proper exercise; abuse remedied case-by-case, not invalidate section.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Matajog Dobey v. H.S. Bhari; Thangal Kunju

respondent_arguments.text: Explanation 1956 validates omnibus orders, covers all proceedings pending/ future.
Petitioners acquiesced, no objection till after Bidi Supply.

court_reasoning.text: S.64 confers benefit/right to local assessment, but subject to tax collection exigencies; not absolute.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Right hedged by exigencies; Dayaldas Kushiram recognizes 'as far as practicable'.

court_reasoning.text: S.5(7A) administrative machinery for efficient assessment; guided by Act's purpose (levy, assess, collect tax); no naked power.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Discretion for complex cases, widespread activities; not discriminatory.

court_reasoning.text: No material discrimination; same procedure post-transfer; minor deviation from s.64 not violate Art 14.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Anwar Ali Sarkar applies only to substantially different procedure.

court_reasoning.text: Presumption officials act bona fide; abuse quash order, not section; assessee can show prima facie discrimination.
Explanation covers all pending/future proceedings any year; omnibus orders valid.
Pre-Constitution transfers (1946) not challengeable; Art 13 no retrospective effect.
Specific transfers justified by evasion, workload, interrelated cases; conveniences afforded; no discrimination.
Prudent to give notice, hear, record reasons before transfer.

holdings.text: Section 5(7A) intra vires, not violative of Articles 14 or 19(1)(g).
Transfer orders valid, not discriminatory/mala fide; Explanation saves omnibus orders.

precedents_cited.case_name: Bidi Supply Co. v. Union of India
precedents_cited.relevance: Omnibus orders invalid if unlimited; left s.5(7A) validity open; Explanation added post this.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of West Bengal v. Anwar Ali Sarkar
precedents_cited.relevance: Discrimination if procedure substantially different; minor deviations ok.
Led to insertion of s.5(7A); s.64 right to local assessment 'as far as practicable'.

precedents_cited.case_name: Keshavan Madhava Menon v. State of Bombay
Dwarka Prasad Laxmi Narain v. State of UP
precedents_cited.relevance: Guidelines needed for discretionary powers affecting rights.

precedents_cited.case_name: Himmatlal Harilal Mehta v. State of MP
Wallace Brothers Co. Ltd. v. CIT Bombay
precedents_cited.relevance: Place of assessment administrative convenience, not jurisdiction.
Presumption against abuse by high officials.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income-tax Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Transfer of cases; place of assessment; overrides local assessment post-transfer.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Equality; trade/business; writs; laws inconsistent with fundamental rights.

outcome.summary: All petitions dismissed as s.5(7A) held constitutional; specific transfers valid, not discriminatory; petitioners disentitled by acquiescence/pre-Constitution actions.
outcome.costs: One set of costs between respondents in each petition; one set per group.

key_quotes.text: "The power is guided and controlled by the purpose which is to be achieved by the Act itself, viz., the charge of income-tax, the assessment and collection thereof."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core reasoning upholding s.5(7A) as not arbitrary.

key_quotes.text: "There is no fundamental right in an assessee to be assessed in a particular area or locality."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "It would be prudent if the principles of natural justice are followed... notice is given... reasons... reduced to writing."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "A plain reading of the section shows that the same is imperative in terms. It also gives to the assessee a valuable right." (Kania J. in Dayaldas)
key_quotes.speaker: petitioner_counsel
